title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. Character education in schools aims to improve students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. It increases self-esteem, reduces isolation, and harmful behavior. Integrating character education into the curriculum fosters the development of core ethical values and virtues in students. Character education initiatives are being promoted by an increasing number of States and local educational agencies. Successful implementation requires access to effective methodologies, high-quality initiatives, professional development opportunities, and networking options. States and local educational agencies need a central source of information to coordinate character education activities in schools. The Secretary is authorized to make a single 5-year grant to an organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, initiatives, curricula, and assessment. Membership should represent various individuals and groups involved in character education. The grant recipient must develop initiatives that address core ethical values, emphasize student behavior, promote caring school communities, allow students to practice character lessons, and involve families and communities in character education. The grant recipient must develop initiatives that address core ethical values, emphasize student behavior, promote caring school communities, allow students to practice character lessons, involve families and communities, emphasize leadership, service, and teamwork, and evaluate the effectiveness of character education initiatives. The grantee will use funds to disseminate information on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, assessment methods, and integration strategies. The grantee will use funds to provide a searchable database, checklist of criteria, and index of websites related to character education initiatives, professional development models, assessment methods, and integration strategies. The grantee will provide a checklist of criteria for schools to assess character education curricula, an index of websites, and telephone assistance. They must submit an annual report detailing progress, information requests, unmet needs, and grant fund usage. The grantee will provide criteria for assessing character education curricula, an index of websites, and telephone assistance. They must submit an annual report detailing progress, information requests, unmet needs, and grant fund usage. Authorization of Appropriations: $750,000 for each fiscal year 2002 through 2006. Grant to conduct character education research. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives, their success, and the needs of schools starting such initiatives are unknown. Efforts should be made to assess the extent of character education in schools, its effectiveness, and the use of federal funds for these initiatives. Schools are implementing character education initiatives, and there is a need to evaluate their effectiveness and the use of Federal funds for these programs. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization with expertise in character education research and practice. The grant recipient must meet specific requirements outlined in the section. The grant recipient must assess character education initiatives in schools, evaluate their effectiveness, and report findings to the Secretary annually. Schools receiving grants must report on their research progress, results, future needs in character education, and grant fund usage. $700,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible organization" is defined as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has submitted a grant application to the Secretary. A "local educational agency" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and a "school" includes elementary schools as defined by the same Act. The term "school" in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 refers to both elementary and secondary schools. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Education.
